stem: An 89-year-old client from a long-term care facility is admitted for 'not acting like himself.' He is confused and cool to the touch. Based on the documentation in the Geriatric Perfusion & Infection Tracking tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute mental status decline in a vulnerable elder.
Background: Chronic indwelling catheter for neurogenic bladder. History of stroke.
Assessment: Client is stuporous. Heart rate is thready. Urine in the bag is cloudy and malodorous.
Recommendation: Immediate sepsis protocol activation.

tabs.title: Geriatric Infection Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Core Temperature95.8°F (35.4°C)Hypothermia (Poor prognostic sign)
Lactate Level3.9 mmol/L (High)Anaerobic Metabolism
Mental StatusCAM+: Acute DeliriumCNS malperfusion
WBC Count4,200 (Low-Normal)No leukocytosis (Aged immune)

actionOptions.text: Initiate IV warm fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics as prescribed
Obtain blood and urine cultures immediately (Before antibiotics)
Administer STAT PO Ibuprofen to treat the underlying inflammation
Place the client in a Trendelenburg position to improve BP

parameterOptions.text: Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) and level of consciousness
Urine output and lung sounds (Check for fluid overload)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Geriatric Septic Shock (c2). Elderly patients often lack the classic 'fever and high WBC' response (Silent Sepsis). Instead, they present with Acute Confusion (Delirium), Hypothermia (95.8°F), and Hypotension. The high Lactate (3.9) confirms shock. Priority actions are culture collection (a2) followed by rehydration/antibiotics (a1). In geriatric patients, monitoring MUST include MAP (p1) AND lung sounds (p2), as they are at high risk for heart failure during rapid fluid resuscitation.
clinicalPearls: Hypothermia (< 96.8°F) in a septic patient is a more dangerous sign than a high fever.
Cloudy/Smelly urine in an elderly patient with acute confusion is 'Urosepsis' until proven otherwise.
The 'Cold' presentation in the elderly is due to an aging hypothalamus and blunted immune response.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the patient doesn't have an infection because the WBC (4,200) is 'Normal'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In elderly sepsis, the WBC often stays normal or even drops (Leukopenia). Never rely on the WBC in geriatric patients; look at the MAP, Lactate, and Mentation.

mnemonic.title: Cold Sepsis
mnemonic.expansion: C-Confusion. O-Out of range (Cold) Temp. L-Low BP. D-Delirium.
